title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.7.17-18 | 31-12-2021
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.text: Om Agyanati Miran Dasya Gyanan Janishalakaya
Chakshurun Meelitam Yena Tasmait Shri Gurave Namaha
Nama Om Vishnu Padaya Krishna Preshtaya Bhutale
Shri Mate Bhakti Vedanta Swamin Nithinamine
Namaste Saraswate Deve Gauravani Pracharine
Nirvishesha Shunyavadi Pashchatya Deshatarine
Jaya Shri Krishna Chaitanya Prabhu Nithyananda
Shri Advaita Gadadhara Shri Vasadi Gaurabhakta Vrinda
Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare
Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare
Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya
Narayanam Namaskritya Naramchaiva Narottamam
Deveem Saraswateem Vyasam Tato Jaya Mudireet
In this session we will be discussing from the
17th and the 18th verses of the 7th chapter of 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam.
From this chapter the narration of the Bhagavatam by Suta Goswami begins and the particular
incident that is being discussed in this chapter is the son of Drona punished, Ashwatthama is
being punished because he beheaded the slave of Drona.
Sleeping sons of Draupadi, so the 17th verse
Iti-priyaam Valgvi chitra jal payi
Sasaantva itva chut緊 mithra Soottha
Anvaadyravat damshita ugradhanva
Kapitvajo guru putram ratvena
The meaning of this verse is Arjuna, who is guided by the infallible Lord as
friend and driver thus satisfied the dear lady by such statements Arjuna
satisfied Draupadi then he dressed in armor and armed himself with furious
weapons and getting into his chariot he set out to follow Ashwatthama the son
of his martial teacher so Ashwatthama had been rejected even by Duryodhana
Duryodhana did not appreciate this act of Ashwatthama unlawful act and Ashwatthama
was actually conscious that his life is in danger
so
he had gone away somewhere so Arjuna who was having Krishna as his friend and
driver
here Krishna is described as Achyutaa infallible Lord. What is the meaning of
infallible he never falls down from his transcendental position
unless he is in deep trance state.
like we the living entities who desire to enjoy materially we give up that
spiritual platform on which we are eternally situated in our relationship
with Krishna we give up that and we come to the material platform so this is
called a a fall a fall down whereas the Supreme Lord and his pure devotees they
never fall down even though they come to the material world they are always
transcendentally situated whether in the material world or in the spiritual world
or any situation any time any place they are always transiently situated so
Arjuna was guided by the infallible Lord the Supreme Lord who is never subject to
any deterioration
he Arjuna satisfied
Draupadi by making significant statements. Now in order to
punish Ashwathama, Arjuna has dressed himself in armor and armed himself with furious weapons
and he got into his chariot he set out to follow Ashwathama.
The 18th verse
The meaning of this verse is Ashwathama the murderer of the princess
seeing from a great distance Arjuna coming at him with great speed fled in his chariot panic-stricken
just to save his life as Brahma fled in fear from Shiva. So Arjuna is trying to
capture Ashwathama to punish him but Ashwathama on seeing that Arjuna is coming
to capture him. Ashwathama is
himself going in his chariot running away from Arjuna just to save his life.
He knew now his life was in danger and here the description is given
The description is given
The description is given
about
Ashwathama running away in fear. The comparison is made just as Brahma ran away in fear
of Lord Shiva. Now Srila Prabhupada explains in the purport
that the word Kaha that is used in the last line of this 18th verse.
Now here the word Kaha refers to Brahma
Or if it is read as Yathar Kaha
Then Arkaha refers to Surya or the sun god
So both those meanings are taken and explained by Prabhupada
According to the reading matter
Either Kaha or Arkaha
There are two references in the Puranas
The Acharyas never speculate
They always refer the Shastra
And clarify such matters
So there is a reference for Kaha
And there is also a reference for Arkaha
Arkaha refers to the sun god
And Kaha refers to Brahma
So it is said with respect to Kaha being used in this verse
Kaha means Brahma
Who once became elude by his daughter
And became a woman
And began to follow her
This infuriated Shiva
Who attacked Brahma with his trident
Brahma fled in fear of his life
This is described in the Puranas
Elsewhere
That
Once Brahma became elude by his own daughter
That is the power of the illusory energy
That such an exalted personality as Brahma
Even he became illusioned
By the sight of his beautiful daughter
He started following her
In order to enjoy with her
So that act of Brahma
Infuriated Shiva
Shiva became very angry
Shiva is also appearing as the son of Brahma
So he became very angry, angry at Brahma
So he became very angry, angry at Brahma
So he became very angry, angry at Brahma
So he became very angry, angry at Brahma
very angry at Brahma, his own father, in terms of the birth Shiva has taken. But he became angry at
Brahma and he went to attack Brahma with his trident. Shiva carries one instrument called
Trishur. With that he attacks those who are unlawful, those who are unnecessarily giving
trouble to saintly persons. So they deserve to be punished. So Shiva became angry against Brahma
for the act of Brahma running behind his daughter and Shiva decided to punish this
person. Brahma began to run away from Shiva fearing his life. Another reference is Arkaha.
Arkaha refers to the sun god. So there is a reference to this in the Vaman Purana.
Srila Prabhupada quotes from Vaman Purana. There was a demon by the name Vidyunmali
who was gifted with
a glowing golden airplane which traveled to the back of the sun.
So there is this Vidyunmali who is a demon and
he received a gift and that gift was a glowing golden airplane. So Vidyunmali decided to utilize
this glowing golden airplane by traveling to the back of the sun
and night disappeared because of the glowing effulgence of this plane,
aeroplane. Aeroplane was very brilliantly shining. So because of that shining of the aeroplane
there was no night.
So Shiva saw then what happened sun god he became angry against this Vidyunmali
that you are disturbing the arrangement of day and night. So what did the sun god do? With his rays
he melted the plane.
In which Vidyunmali was traveling.
Now Shiva observed this.
He became very very angry against sun god. Then Shiva attacked the sun god
and
sun god in order to escape from
his
abode.
He became very very angry against the sun god and he wore aூbhi one day.
Shiva he ran away and fell at Kashi or Varanasi. And the fame and the place became famous as Lolarka.
So these type of descriptions are given in the puranas but we have to hear and understand the import of such descriptions with reference to the context in the world.
which gives us a lot of information in the world. For example this description of the planet house.
In the short description of the sun god has mentioned that the sun god is famous for his Original form.
This description of the sun god is known only as the sun god who was in God in ancient times.
There is another description that says in this scripture.
to the context in which it is described now in this situation how Ashwatthama is
running away from Arjuna therefore these comparisons are being made when life is
in danger they'll do anything to save their themselves or save their life
that's natural for any human being but in the course of escaping whether they
really be able to save their life that is not assured or that's not guaranteed
of course the Bhagavatam advises everyone take shelter of Krishna even
Bhagavad Gita also advises take shelter of Krishna
once somebody takes shelter of Krishna then they need not fear anyone or
anything else any other danger no but it's not easy to approach Krishna only
pure devotees can approach Krishna and others have to engage in some
confidential service to the Supreme Lord Krishna by which
Krishna is attracted to the devotee otherwise approaching Krishna is not
possible for everyone so therefore it is said here that the sun god who was
trying to escape the wrath of Shiva the anger of Shiva he fell down in Kashi and
so this sort of incidents help us understand that material world elsewhere
proper explains every step there is danger and the safest place for us is
the spiritual world the spiritual platform in which there is no danger
there is no difficulty there is no death there is no material influence like that
so I'll stop here thank you very much Hare Krishna
